content:
The White Tree of Gondor is a symbol of the city of Minas Tirith and the royal line of Gondor. The tree is a sapling of the tree Nimloth, which was a gift to the people of Numenor by the Elves of Tol Eressea.

In the early days of Gondor, the tree was planted in the court of the fountain in the Citadel of Minas Tirith and was highly revered by the people of Gondor, who saw it as a symbol of their connection to the ancient kingdom of Numenor.

The tree was believed to have special powers, and it was said that as long as the tree remained healthy, Gondor would flourish. But during the Stewardship of Denethor II, the tree began to wither and die, and it was seen as a sign that the kingdom of Gondor was in peril.

In the time of war, Gandalf the White, brought a sapling of the tree from the seedling that was guarded by the Dunedain of the North and planted it in Minas Tirith, signifying the re-birth of Gondor and the hope for the future.

The White Tree of Gondor continues to be a powerful symbol of the city and the kingdom of Gondor, and it is an important part of the city's history and culture. It's a symbol of the continuity and resilience of the people of Gondor.
